title: Cuomo Urges More New Yorkers to Get Tested for Coronavirus
description: In New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio warned residents to avoid crowding on city beaches, saying they could be shut down completely if necessary.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo wants thousands more New Yorkers to get tested for the coronavirus — so much so that he got tested during his live news briefing in Albany on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Autoworkers Are Returning as Carmakers Gradually Crank Up Factories
description: After being idle for nearly two months, G.M., Ford and Fiat Chrysler will restart assembly plants on Monday with masks, gloves and curtains.
content: After sheltering at home for nearly two months, tens of thousands of autoworkers have started streaming back into car and truck plants across the South and Midwest, a critical step toward bringing the nation’s largest manufacturing industry back to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Stenquist
title: A (Barely) Controlled Explosion, and 330 M.P.H. Before You Can Blink
description: An inside look at the engines that propel the funny cars of drag racing from zero to you-can’t-be-serious in four seconds.
content: At the head of a straight ribbon of pavement, a swarm of technicians and worker bees is attending to an odd contraption — a seeming cross between a car and the Batmobile. A brief, explosive show is about to thrill thousands watching from the grandstands.
source.name: The New York Times

title: To the Class of 2020
description: A high school senior reflects on shared experiences and a changed world. Also: A young teenager yearns for his real life.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: China Virus Cluster, Yemen, Cirque du Soleil: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: Ending Crisis, Israel Swears in Netanyahu-Led Government to Rescue Economy
description: A unity government with Benny Gantz, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s former rival, will brace for a second wave of the coronavirus while restoring “jobs, jobs, jobs,” Mr. Netanyahu promises.
content: JERUSALEM — Ending a 510-day political crisis that three elections had failed to resolve, Israel on Sunday swore in a new government charged with responding to the coronavirus pandemic, extending Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s record-setting tenure just a week before his corruption trial is set to begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Roberts
title: Forty Years Later, Lessons for the Pandemic From Mount St. Helens
description: The tensions we now face between science, politics and economics also arose before the country’s most destructive volcanic eruption.
content: When I met David A. Johnston, it was on a spring evening, about a month before he would be erased from existence by a gigantic cloud of volcanic ash boiling over him at 300 miles per hour. He was coming through the door of a makeshift command center in Vancouver, Wash., the closest city to the graceful snow-capped dome of Mount St. Helens, a volcano that had been dormant for 123 years. This was April 1980, and Mr. Johnston, a 30-year-old geologist, was one of the first scientists summoned to monitor new warning signs from the mountain — shallow earthquakes and periodic bursts of ash and steam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: I’ll Take Biden’s Confusion Over Trump’s Corruption
description: Let’s not repeat the false equivalence of 2016.
content: Please tell me why I should care whether Joe Biden is declining mentally when Donald Trump bottomed out morally long ago.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Nigerian Coronavirus Outbreak Highlights Emerging Threat in Africa
description: China has quarantined thousands of people after a resurgence of cases in the Northeast. The leaders of Italy and Britain warned that a vaccine may be a long time coming.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow live global updates on the coronavirus here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ayelet Bentley, Samuel Tbeile
description: They met in college and became a couple about a year later while on a Birthright Israel trip.
content: Ayelet Meryl Bentley and Samuel Joshua Tbeile are to be married May 17. Rabbi Meyer Laniado is to officiate at the Wadsworth Mansion in Middletown, Conn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: Ending Crisis, Israel Swears in Netanyahu-Led Government to Rescue Economy
description: A unity government with Benny Gantz, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s former rival, will brace for a second wave of the coronavirus while restoring “jobs, jobs, jobs,” Mr. Netanyahu promises.
content: JERUSALEM — Ending a 510-day political crisis that three elections had failed to resolve, Israel on Sunday swore in a new government charged with responding to the coronavirus pandemic, extending Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s record-setting tenure just a week before his corruption trial is set to begin.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Nigerian Coronavirus Outbreak Highlights Emerging Threat in Africa
description: China has quarantined thousands of people after a resurgence of cases in the Northeast. The leaders of Italy and Britain warned that a vaccine may be a long time coming.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow live global updates on the coronavirus here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Roberts
title: Forty Years Later, Lessons for the Pandemic From Mount St. Helens
description: The tensions we now face between science, politics and economics also arose before the country’s most destructive volcanic eruption.
content: When I met David A. Johnston, it was on a spring evening, about a month before he would be erased from existence by a gigantic cloud of volcanic ash boiling over him at 300 miles per hour. He was coming through the door of a makeshift command center in Vancouver, Wash., the closest city to the graceful snow-capped dome of Mount St. Helens, a volcano that had been dormant for 123 years. This was April 1980, and Mr. Johnston, a 30-year-old geologist, was one of the first scientists summoned to monitor new warning signs from the mountain — shallow earthquakes and periodic bursts of ash and steam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: I’ll Take Biden’s Confusion Over Trump’s Corruption
description: Let’s not repeat the false equivalence of 2016.
content: Please tell me why I should care whether Joe Biden is declining mentally when Donald Trump bottomed out morally long ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: ‘Straight-Up Fire’ in His Veins: Teen Battles New Covid Syndrome
description: Jack McMorrow, 14, awoke in agony, with heart failure. His case may help doctors understand a frightening new affliction in children linked to the coronavirus.
content: When a sprinkling of a reddish rash appeared on Jack McMorrow’s hands in mid-April, his father figured the 14-year-old was overusing hand sanitizer — not a bad thing during a global pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: As Cable TV Fades, Fearing ‘the End of Comedy Central’
description: The network that made the careers of Dave Chappelle, Stephen Colbert and Amy Schumer has laid off top executives while looking to make shows that are cheaper to produce.
content: Last year there were signs of hope for Comedy Central. Trevor Noah, the host of “The Daily Show” since 2015, had found his footing. New series like “The Other Two” and “South Side” got strong reviews. Awkwafina, the breakout star of “Crazy Rich Asians” and “The Farewell,” came aboard for a new show.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘I Can’t Turn My Brain Off’
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 17, 2020.
content: “The virus scares the hell out of our guys. And now, when they go home to decompress, instead they and their spouses are home-schooling. The spouse has lost a job, and is at wit’s end. The kids are screaming. Let me tell you: The tension level in the crews is through the roof.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Snowpiercer’ and Taylor Swift
description: An adaptation of Bong Joon Ho’s action movie debuts on TNT, and a Taylor Swift concert airs on ABC.
content: SNOWPIERCER 9 p.m. on TNT. Jennifer Connelly and Daveed Diggs star in this postapocalyptic drama series, based on the action flick of the same name by the director Bong Joon Ho (“Parasite”) and its source material, the French graphic novel series “Le Transperceneige.” The title refers to the show’s setting: a 1,001-car train that continuously circles the Earth after the planet has frozen and become unlivable. Yet worldly evils remain, namely class divides, social injustice and greed. Tensions reach a fever pitch when someone is killed in first class and Melanie Cavill (Connelly), the head of hospitality, seeks the help of Andre Layton (Diggs), a rebellious third-class passenger and the only surviving homicide detective on the planet. The series has been five years in the making, buts its debut comes two weeks earlier than planned. And TNT has already ordered a second season.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Must Present a Compelling Case for Keeping the Item in Question’
description: A couple’s deal on what passes for trash, a first kiss in Brooklyn and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
title: Chinese Ambassador Is Found Dead at Home in Israel
description: An embassy worker found the body of Du Wei, 57, in his bed in a coastal suburb north of Tel Aviv, Israeli officials said. The Chinese government in preliminary findings attributed his death to unspecified health problems.
content: JERUSALEM — China’s ambassador to Israel, who took up his post in February, was found dead at his home on Sunday morning in a coastal suburb north of Tel Aviv, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Trump Looks Forward to the Return of Sports With Crowds
description: The president called in to the broadcast of the golf tour’s first live TV event since the coronavirus pandemic shuttered tournaments.
content: In a telephone appearance during a televised charity golf exhibition on Sunday, President Trump enthusiastically supported the return of live sports events during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Padilla
title: Black Deliveryman Says He Was Blocked and Interrogated by White Driver
description: Travis Miller Sr. said he was trying to leave a gated neighborhood in Oklahoma after a delivery when a vehicle blocked his path.
content: Travis Miller Sr., an appliance and furniture deliveryman, had just completed his eighth and last delivery of the day last Monday and was attempting to leave a gated community with a co-worker when a white car blocked his path to the neighborhood’s only exit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: S. David Freeman, 94, Tireless Advocate for Clean Energy, Dies
description: A folksy but forceful “Green Cowboy,” he helped shape energy policy in the White House and at local utilities for seven decades.
content: S. David Freeman, a folksy but driven “green cowboy” who worked in energy policy under three presidents, ran some of the nation’s largest public utilities and pushed for renewable energy, died on Tuesday in Reston, Va. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: How France Lost the Weapons to Fight a Pandemic
description: The French once thought of medical gear, like fighter jets, as a national security asset that had to be made at home. But cuts and outsourcing have left them scrambling for masks, tests and even pain pills.
content: PARIS — When President Emmanuel Macron repeatedly declared “war” on the coronavirus in March, he solemnly promised that France would support “front-line” health workers with “the means, the protection.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Will Cirque du Soleil Rise Again?
description: The coronavirus has pulverized the famed circus, forcing it to shut down dozens of shows and grounding its small army of circus artists.
content: MONTREAL — Until the coronavirus pandemic hit, the Mongolian contortionist Uranbileg Angarag wowed spectators nightly at Cirque du Soleil shows on a cruise ship, contorting her body into a ball and balancing on a vertical stick held in her mouth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Arthur, the First Named Storm of the Hurricane Season, Forms
description: A tropical storm warning was issued for the North Carolina’s Outer Banks, the National Hurricane Center said.
content: The first named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season formed off the coast of Florida on Saturday, making it the sixth consecutive year that a system formed before the official June 1 start of the season, the National Hurricane Center said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malachy Browne, Drew Jordan, Dmitriy Khavin and Ainara Tiefenthäler
title: Ahmaud Arbery’s Final Minutes: What Videos and 911 Calls Show
description: Using security footage, cellphone video, 911 calls and police reports, The Times has reconstructed the 12 minutes before Ahmaud Arbery was shot dead in Georgia on Feb. 23.
content: Using security footage, cellphone video, 911 calls and police reports, The Times has reconstructed the 12 minutes before Ahmaud Arbery was shot dead in Georgia on Feb. 23.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Obama Lives in Trump’s Head
description: The president feels the need to shower lies and blame upon his predecessor.
content: No one irritates Donald Trump quite like Barack Obama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: How Many Covid Deaths? Don’t Ask President Trump
description: The president has expressed skepticism about the fatality figures reported to him by his own experts.
content: The fatality numbers are, to be sure, heartbreaking: more than 85,000 Americans dead and more than 1.4 million infected. But many public health experts, including some within the Trump administration, have been stressing that, if anything, Covid-19 deaths and cases are being undercounted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Illinois Threatens to Fine Defiant Businesses as Reopening Tensions Rise Nationally
description: Fed chair warns full economic recovery may await vaccine, while Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York has a public nasal swab to encourage testing.
content: The owners of restaurants, bars and other establishments in Illinois that open too soon can now be charged with a Class A misdemeanor under a measure enacted by the governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Chair Says Economic Recovery May ‘Stretch’ Through End of 2021
description: Jerome H. Powell, who heads the central bank, predicted a slow economic recovery and reiterated that policymakers may need to do more.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said that the United States would have a slow recovery from what he called the “biggest shock that the economy’s had in living memory,” suggesting that a full rebound from virus-induced lockdowns could take until the end of 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Ready or Not, Here Comes the Reopening
description: Businesses start coming back to life, but will it lead to a resurgence of virus cases?
content: What letter will the economic recovery resemble? Everyone wants it to be a “V” — after a precipitous fall, straight up from here. But more realistic forecasters warn that it’ll likely be a long, wide “U,” taking years to rebuild. Scarier yet, some health officials say that we could see a “W” if the country reopens too early and there’s a resurgence of cases. Here’s the rest of the business news you need to know for the week ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: The Museum Is Closed, but Its Tomato Man Soldiers On
description: Although the Guggenheim’s “Countryside” show was shuttered by the pandemic, its crop of cherry tomatoes is still growing, and feeding New Yorkers.
content: The halls of the Guggenheim Museum are pretty quiet these days, with mostly just its ghosts and some security guards as company for the art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Moses Sumney and Perfume Genius: Complex Voices of Desire
description: Two new albums by musicians who have taken on a spectrum of love and longing explore more ambitious sonic possibilities.
content: Sexual desire is always complicated. It’s a profoundly individual tangle of physical and psychological actions and responses, and it’s inseparable from flesh and circumstance, from instinct and memory and culture. It grows even more complex when those desires are seen as abnormal, outside the mainstream, unacceptable or even immoral — attitudes that an adolescent can internalize and an adult can struggle to outgrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 18, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Note: This is our final photograph for the 2019-20 school year. Please visit our archive to find hundreds of other images you can use between now and September, when we will resume this feature. You can also sign up for our free weekly newsletter to make sure you don’t miss any of our new images.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Iran Summons Ambassador Over Possible U.S. Threat to Venezuela Shipment
description: Iran summoned the Swiss ambassador, who represents U.S. interests in the Islamic Republic, over possible measures America could take against an Iranian fuel shipment to Venezuela.
content: Iran summoned the Swiss ambassador, who represents U.S. interests in the Islamic Republic, over possible measures the United States could take against an Iranian fuel shipment to Venezuela, the Mehr news agency reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Japan Falls Into Recession, and Worse Lies Ahead
description: Despite signs of success in fighting the coronavirus, the world’s third-largest economy will struggle for months to come as it tries to reopen for business.
content: Japan fell into a recession for the first time since 2015, as its already weakened economy was dragged down by the coronavirus’s impact on businesses at home and abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Afghan Rivals Sign Power-Sharing Deal as Political Crisis Subsides
description: President Ashraf Ghani gave Abdullah Abdullah the leading role in seeking peace with the Taliban and the ability to name half the cabinet.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s monthslong election dispute, which resulted in the bizarre reality of two men taking the oath of office as president, reached a resolution on Sunday when President Ashraf Ghani gave his chief rival, Abdullah Abdullah, the leading role in the country’s peace process with the Taliban and the right to appoint half the cabinet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Glitches in Online A.P. Tests Add to Students’ Anxieties
description: Technical problems with the digital versions of the Advanced Placement exams caused angst for high school students and parents at an already stressful time.
content: Julia Rock-Torcivia had everything in place for her Advanced Placement chemistry test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Without Fans, Some College Football Games Won’t Make Financial Sense
description: There are nearly 30 games scheduled for neutral sites in the coming season. Financially, they become somewhat untenable if the coronavirus forces them to go without fans.
content: When Alabama and Southern California agreed to kick off the season on Sept. 5 in Arlington, Texas, the one certain winner seemed to be the host — the Dallas Cowboys’ owner, Jerry Jones, whose Labor Day weekend game has become a college football staple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Popescu and Aimee Ortiz
title: At Least 12 Firefighters Injured After Explosion in Downtown Los Angeles
description: Two firefighters were in critical condition after a blaze at a building that houses smoking and vaping products, officials said.
content: LOS ANGELES — The firefighters realized something was wrong inside the building in downtown Los Angeles on Saturday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Canadian Military Jet Crashes During Flyover for Coronavirus Workers, Killing One
description: Another member of the military was injured, the authorities said. The jet crashed into a house in Kamloops, British Columbia.
content: A Canadian Air Force jet crashed, killing one of the military personnel on board, in Kamloops, British Columbia, on Sunday during a flyover that was intended as a tribute to Canadians, especially those on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Vowell
title: How Democrats Win in My Red State (and They Do Win)
description: For the shrewd Montana Democrat, good government and good politics are often indistinguishable.
content: BOZEMAN, Mont. — The only reason to be a Democrat running for statewide office in Montana is that, alas, you are one. Just keep in mind that there will be none of that heady, audacity-of-hope-type jazz. In this cold, conservative state, your mission is to persuade the skeptics east of the Rocky Mountain Front that you are a levelheaded, friendly, capitalist adult who won’t be levitating the Pentagon — a task that has gotten considerably easier since the Republican establishment lost interest in basic empiricism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Wandering a Grand Hotel Emptied by Coronavirus, and Checking 1,400 Taps
description: A luxury hotel in Barcelona plans to welcome guests again once Spain’s lockdown ends. Until then, its sole occupant lives in a room with enviable views and preps it for a post-pandemic world.
content: BARCELONA, Spain — Every five days, Daniel Ordoñez opens 1,400 pipe taps in a waterfront hotel here in Barcelona that locals call “The Sail” because of its shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Is Ronan Farrow Too Good to Be True?
description: He has delivered revelatory reporting on some of the defining stories of our time. But a close examination reveals the weaknesses in what may be called an era of resistance journalism.
content: It was a breathtaking story, written by The New Yorker’s marquee reporter and published with an attention-grabbing headline: “Missing Files Motivated the Leak of Michael Cohen’s Financial Records.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Inspector General’s Firing Puts Pompeo’s Use of Taxpayer Funds Under Scrutiny
description: Accusations of improperly using government resources have trailed the secretary of state, but President Trump’s move to fire the State Department inspector general has handed Democrats a new weapon.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo swatted away questions about his use of government resources again and again last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Covid-19 Outbreak in Nigeria Is Just One of Africa’s Alarming Hot Spots
description: Dozens of doctors are infected and gravediggers are overwhelmed in Kano, Nigeria’s second-largest city, where inaction led to an unchecked outbreak. Across Africa, other hot spots are emerging.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — In the northern Nigerian city of Kano, some people say they now get four or five death notices on their phones each day: A colleague has died. A friend’s aunt. A former classmate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Melina Delkic
title: As States Reopen, Governors Balance Existing Risks With New Ones
description: The costs of the coronavirus shutdown, economic and otherwise, have driven many people to the breaking point. But governors are increasingly worried about the costs of reopening, too.
content: The pain of the coronavirus shutdown, in terms of wrecked economies and shattered lives, has been unmistakable. Now, governors across the country are contemplating the risks of reopening, particularly if it produces a surge of new cases and deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goggin
title: My Cancer Doesn’t Care About the Coronavirus
description: I’ve seen a new layer of anxiety, and heroism, during my lonely treatment visits.
content: There is a checkpoint as you enter the Kimmel Cancer Center at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, where I am being treated for cancer of the prostate and lymph nodes. With all but two sets of doors to the building locked shut, patients are corralled into an area roped off from the rest of the first-floor lobby. You are required to show your orange Hopkins patient identification card and proof that you have an appointment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kathy Su, Eric Schultz
description: The couple met in 2017 through OkCupid and had their first date at a whiskey bar in New York.
content: Kathy Su and Eric Paul Schultz were married May 16 in Mesa, Ariz. Wade R. Swanson, a cousin of the groom and a Universal Life minister, officiated in the backyard of his home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: State of the Virus, Barack Obama, Baseball: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Sunday Read’: Letters of Recommendation
description: Our worlds are smaller now. So for today, expand yours by peering through the views offered by a writer’s window, a grandmother’s diary and a believer’s superstition.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Shell Game
description: Christina Iverson continues our streak of playful crosswords.
content: WORDPLAY, THE CROSSWORD COLUMN
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Oil Prices Stage a Modest Recovery as Demand Rises and Supply Drops
description: The U.S. benchmark approached $30 a barrel, a month after briefly falling below zero, but it’s still far from where it was before the pandemic.
content: HOUSTON — Driving in the United States and Europe is picking up a little. Refineries in China are buying more oil as that country’s economy reopens. Saudi Arabia and Russia ended their price war and slashed production, and American oil companies are decommissioning rigs and shutting wells.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: This might be the perfect time for Mark Bittman’s ribollita, paired with garlic bread, or a big salad with grains.
content: Good morning. There was a great moment the other day as I was driving down to the market for supplies, a rare traffic jam on a stretch of road that’s generally barren, cars backed up in both directions so that a family of Canada geese could waddle across the road, moving from a pond on one side to the bay on the other. The mother goose had her neck stretched low to the pavement, guiding the goslings along, and if Michael the police officer wasn’t there with his whistle to help, it was still reminiscent of Robert McCloskey’s “Make Way for Ducklings,” and I knew every driver in line was smiling behind her mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iliana Magra
title: Illinois Shooting Suspect Found Dead After Standoff at Super 8 Motel
description: One person was killed and two others wounded in the northern city of Rockford before a barricaded suspect died by what appeared to be a “self-inflicted” gunshot wound, the police said.
content: A burst of violence on Sunday morning at a Super 8 motel in Northern Illinois ended with one person killed, two others wounded and a suspect who was barricaded for hours inside the building dead of what appeared to be a “self-inflicted” gunshot wound, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah, Matthew Bloch and Scott Reinhard
title: Where New Yorkers Moved to Escape Coronavirus
description: As some of New York's wealthiest neighborhoods emptied out, mail-forwarding requests show us where they went.
content: As some of New York's wealthiest neighborhoods emptied out, mail-forwarding requests show us where they went.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roy Furchgott
title: A Generation Gap in Car Wax
description: Younger car owners are more likely to see their vehicle as utilitarian, and they’re trickier for product makers to market to.
content: Millennials don’t love their cars the way their elders did, and if you make car wax, that’s a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fathers, Sons, Forgiveness and Regrets
description: Readers respond to a Sunday Review essay with their own experiences, personal and professional.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Seeking: Big Democratic Ideas That Make Everything Better
description: By the end of primary season, the Democratic Party had all but settled on a conventional center-left agenda. But the pandemic is forcing the Biden campaign and other leaders to redraw plans for 2021.
content: More than 36 million Americans are suddenly unemployed. Congress has allocated $2.2 trillion in aid, with more likely to be on the way as a fight looms over government debt. Millions more people are losing their health insurance and struggling to take care of their children and aging relatives. And nearly 90,000 are dead in a continuing public health catastrophe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Immigration Agency That Issues Visas, Green Cards Struggles to Stay Afloat
description: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services has asked Congress for a lifeline amid the coronavirus pandemic that has caused applications to plummet and brought it to the brink of insolvency.
content: LOS ANGELES — A precipitous drop in applications for green cards, citizenship and other programs has threatened the solvency of the federal agency that administers the country’s lawful immigration system, prompting it to seek a $1.2 billion cash infusion from Congress as well as fee hikes to stay afloat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Padilla
title: 2 Kansas City Officers Charged With Assaulting Transgender Woman
description: Prosecutors said the officers slammed Breona Hill to the sidewalk and kneed her in the face, torso and ribs in an episode that a passer-by captured on video.
content: Two Kansas City, Mo., police officers have been indicted on assault charges a year after they were caught on video using excessive force to arrest a transgender woman, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: In the Shadows of America’s Smokestacks, Virus Is One More Deadly Risk
description: Nationwide, poor communities  are exposed to much more air pollution than wealthier ones. Scientists are racing to understand what role this may play in  Covid-19.
content: This isn’t the first time Vicki Dobbins’s town has been forced to shelter in place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali-Asghar Abedi
title: The Silver Lining of Being Quarantined During Ramadan
description: Being at home with family has made observing Islam’s holiest month a richer and deeper spiritual experience.
content: When Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York announced that lockdown would be extended through May 15, I wondered how this would affect Ramadan. After all, dinner parties and communal prayers have long been integral to this month, which began on April 24. But rather unexpectedly, quarantine has enhanced my Ramadan experience. Being at home has made it easier to observe our holiest month and made it a richer and deeper spiritual affair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles C. Camosy
title: What’s Behind the Nursing Home Horror
description: After decades of mistreatment, older Americans are bearing the worst of the pandemic.
content: We knew it from the beginning. A nursing home in Washington State was the center of the first known coronavirus outbreak in the United States. We knew that institutions caring for the elderly and disabled in close quarters would be particularly vulnerable during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: Dump on Your Office All You Like. You’ll Miss It When It’s Gone.
description: Your workplace shaped your identity in ways you never knew.
content: The office, for the foreseeable future, is dead. Google and Facebook are telling employees they can work remotely until 2021. Twitter is allowing employees to work from home “forever.” A number of big banks are contemplating never fully refilling their office towers in Manhattan. Last week, my colleague Matthew Haag wrote a thoroughly depressing story in which the chief executive of Halstead Real Estate asked him point blank: “Looking forward, are people going to want to crowd into offices?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: One More Relationship Tested by the Pandemic: Siblings
description: For many brothers and sisters, the coronavirus and its limits on relationships outside the home have upended their dynamics.
content: The isolation and close quarters of self-quarantine have shifted the balance in relationships between spouses and partners, employees and bosses, children and parents, students and teachers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: Why Driving in New York City Now Feels ‘Post-Apocalyptic’
description: Fifth Avenue moves like a country road. The F.D.R. Drive is smooth sailing. The coronavirus pandemic has made steering a car through the city an eerily normal activity.
content: A late morning drive down Fifth Avenue, starting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where the lanes are normally choked with inching traffic, now passes by almost impossibly quickly. Glance down at the speedometer, and you might miss Rockefeller Center.
source.name: The New York Times
